verses.text: Now when Jesus learned that the Pharisees had heard that He was making and baptizing more disciples than John—
verses.comment: The context notes Jesus' rising influence. Baptism is highlighted here, connecting Jesus' ministry with John's but also showing continuity and development of the practice.

verses.text: —though Jesus Himself was not baptizing, but His disciples were—
verses.comment: While Jesus delegates baptism to His disciples, it shows the importance of apostolic participation, foreshadowing ministry by those sent by Christ.

verses.text: He left Judea and went back again to Galilee.
verses.comment: Jesus often departs when opposition increases, showing His control over His mission timing.

verses.text: Now He had to pass through Samaria.
verses.comment: Traveling through Samaria was uncommon for Jews because of tensions with Samaritans. Jesus bridges cultural divides—a spiritual and practical act.

verses.text: So He came to a town of Samaria called Sychar, near the field that Jacob had given to his son Joseph.
verses.comment: Sychar is rich in Israel's heritage, connecting Jesus to the patriarchs. This underlines fulfillment of God's plan and Jesus as Messiah for all.

verses.text: Jacob’s well was there. So Jesus, worn out from His journey, sat down by the well. It was about the sixth hour.
verses.comment: Jesus’ weariness highlights His true humanity, affirming the incarnation—God Himself experiencing human limits (see Phil. 2:6-8).

verses.text: A woman from Samaria came to draw water. Jesus said to her, “Give Me a drink.”
verses.comment: Crossing social boundaries, Jesus initiates conversation. Like with Rebekah and Rachel at the well, meetings here are significant in salvation history.

verses.text: For His disciples had gone into the city to buy food.
verses.comment: The disciples’ absence allows Jesus to hold a personal conversation, emphasizing His direct outreach.

verses.text: The Samaritan woman said to Him, “How is it that You, a Jew, ask a drink from me, a Samaritan woman?” (For Jews do not associate with Samaritans.)
verses.comment: Hostility between Jews and Samaritans was deep. Jesus’ outreach foreshadows the breaking down of barriers through His Church.

verses.text: Jesus answered her, “If you knew the gift of God, and who it is that is saying to you, ‘Give Me a drink,’ you would have asked Him, and He would have given you living water.”
verses.comment: Jesus subtly reveals His divine identity and offers grace. 'Living water' is a metaphor for the Holy Spirit and eternal life, promised through the Messiah.

verses.text: The woman said to Him, “Sir, You have nothing to draw water with, and the well is deep. Where then do You get that living water?
verses.comment: She thinks literally, missing Jesus' spiritual meaning. This theme recurs throughout John’s Gospel as people misunderstand Jesus’ deeper teaching.

verses.text: Are You greater than our father Jacob, who gave us the well and drank from it himself, as did his sons and his livestock?”
verses.comment: By calling Jacob 'father,' she claims spiritual heritage. Ironically, Jesus is far greater than Jacob, pointing to His divine sonship.

verses.text: Jesus answered and said to her, “Everyone who drinks of this water will be thirsty again,
verses.comment: The physical water symbolizes temporal satisfaction; Jesus offers an eternal gift.

verses.text: but whoever drinks of the water that I will give him will never be thirsty forever. The water that I will give him will become in him a spring of water welling up to eternal life.”
verses.comment: Jesus offers not merely eternal life but the indwelling gift of grace, an inward transformation—a key New Covenant theme.

verses.text: The woman said to Him, “Sir, give me this water, so that I will not be thirsty or have to come here to draw water.”
verses.comment: Still thinking physically, the woman expresses a desire for comfort but does not yet understand Jesus’ promise.

verses.text: Jesus said to her, “Go, call your husband, and come here.”
verses.comment: Jesus gently exposes her need for healing and truth, preparing her for deeper revelation.

verses.text: The woman answered Him, “I have no husband.” Jesus said to her, “You are right in saying, ‘I have no husband,’
verses.comment: This dialogue invites honesty and self-knowledge, vital for repentance and receiving grace.

verses.text: for you have had five husbands, and the one you now have is not your husband. What you have said is true.”
verses.comment: Jesus demonstrates supernatural knowledge, revealing His prophetic and more-than-human insight (cf. John 1:48-51).

verses.text: The woman said to Him, “Sir, I perceive that You are a prophet.
verses.comment: She recognizes a prophetic role in Jesus, foreshadowing the expected Prophet like Moses, but something even greater is being revealed.

verses.text: Our fathers worshiped on this mountain, but you say that in Jerusalem is the place where people ought to worship.”
verses.comment: The woman raises worship disputes: Samaritans worshipped on Mount Gerizim, Jews in Jerusalem. Jesus will transcend both.

verses.text: Jesus said to her, “Woman, believe Me, the hour is coming when neither on this mountain nor in Jerusalem will you worship the Father.
verses.comment: Worship will soon be universal and no longer restricted to an earthly location, pointing to the fulfillment of New Covenant worship.

verses.text: You worship what you do not know; we worship what we know, for salvation is from the Jews.
verses.comment: Jesus affirms the Jewish roots of salvation and fulfillment of God's promises through Israel. The Messiah comes through this lineage.

verses.text: But the hour is coming, and now is here, when the true worshipers will worship the Father in spirit and in truth, for the Father is seeking such people to worship Him.
verses.comment: Worship in spirit and truth anticipates the universal, spiritual worship established by Christ, beyond physical boundaries.

verses.text: God is spirit, and those who worship Him must worship in spirit and truth.”
verses.comment: True worship is founded on God's very nature and is made possible by sharing in His Spirit.

verses.text: The woman said to Him, “I know that Messiah is coming, who is called Christ. When He comes, He will tell us everything.”
verses.comment: She expresses common Samaritan messianic hope. Jesus is about to declare His identity explicitly.

verses.text: Jesus said to her, “I am He, the one who is speaking to you.”
verses.comment: This is a direct claim to being the Messiah. The Greek echoes the divine 'I am,' underscoring Jesus’ divinity.

verses.text: Just then His disciples came back. They marveled that He was talking with a woman, but no one said, “What do You seek?” or, “Why are You talking with her?”
verses.comment: The encounter was counter-cultural, showing Jesus’ openness and the dignity He gives to all people, regardless of social norms.

verses.text: So the woman left her water jar and went away into the town and said to the people,
verses.comment: Leaving her jar shows a shift of focus; encountering Christ transforms priorities.

verses.text: "Come, see a man who told me everything I ever did. Can this be the Christ?"
verses.comment: Her witness leads others to seek Jesus. Personal testimony is a means of evangelization and conversion.

verses.text: They went out of the town and were coming to Him.
verses.comment: Her testimony bears fruit as the community comes to inquire of Christ personally.

verses.text: Meanwhile, the disciples were urging Him, saying, “Rabbi, eat!”
verses.comment: 'Rabbi' recognizes Jesus as teacher, but the disciples remain concerned with earthly needs.

verses.text: But He said to them, “I have food to eat that you do not know about.”
verses.comment: Jesus points to spiritual nourishment and obedience to the Father as His sustenance.

verses.text: So the disciples said to one another, “Has anyone brought Him something to eat?”
verses.comment: Once again, the disciples misunderstand Jesus’ deeper meaning, focused on the external.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, “My food is to do the will of Him who sent Me and to finish His work.
verses.comment: Obedience to the Father's plan is Jesus’ sustenance. This anticipates His total self-offering for the salvation of the world.

verses.text: Do you not say, ‘There are yet four months, then comes the harvest’? Look, I tell you, lift up your eyes and see that the fields are white for harvest.
verses.comment: Jesus calls the disciples to recognize that the time for mission—the gathering of all people—is now.

verses.text: The one who reaps is already receiving wages and gathering fruit for eternal life, so that the sower and reaper may rejoice together.
verses.comment: Both sowers and reapers (prophets and apostles) share joy in God’s abundant harvest. This reflects the unity and continuity of God’s work.

verses.text: For here the saying holds true, ‘One sows and another reaps.’
verses.comment: Prophets laid foundations; the apostles now reap. It shows the Church grows by the faith of both Old and New Testament saints.

verses.text: I sent you to reap what you did not labor for. Others have labored, and you have entered into their labor.”
verses.comment: The apostolic mission is built on what came before: God’s plan encompasses all ages and peoples.

verses.text: Many Samaritans from that town believed in Him because of the woman’s testimony, “He told me everything I ever did.”
verses.comment: Lay witness is powerful in bringing others to belief, but ultimately faith comes through encountering Christ personally.

verses.text: So when the Samaritans came to Him, they asked Him to stay with them. And He stayed there two days.
verses.comment: Jesus responds to sincere seeking by remaining with them—a sign of God’s presence now being extended to all nations.

verses.text: And many more believed because of His word.
verses.comment: Hearing the word of Christ is the foundation of true faith—faith comes by hearing (see Rom. 10:17).

verses.text: They said to the woman, “No longer do we believe because of what you said, for we have heard for ourselves, and we know that this is truly the Savior of the world.”
verses.comment: Jesus is declared Savior of all humanity, not just Israel—a universal mission. Personal encounter leads to deeper faith.

verses.text: After the two days He departed from there for Galilee.
verses.comment: Jesus completes His mission among the Samaritans, then continues on the path set by the Father.

verses.text: For Jesus Himself had testified that a prophet has no honor in his own country.
verses.comment: Jesus’ statement echoes the Old Testament experience of prophets and confirms the challenge of being accepted at home.

verses.text: So when He came to Galilee, the Galileans welcomed Him, having seen all that He had done in Jerusalem at the feast, for they themselves also had been at the feast.
verses.comment: Jesus’ reputation spreads through His public ministry and the signs He performs, attracting attention and faith.

verses.text: So He came again to Cana in Galilee, where He had made the water wine. And at Capernaum there was a royal official whose son was ill.
verses.comment: Returning to Cana recalls His first sign, linking Jesus’ ministry with miracles of mercy that reveal His glory.

verses.text: When this man heard that Jesus had come from Judea to Galilee, he went and asked Him to come down and heal his son, for he was at the point of death.
verses.comment: Faith leads the official to seek Jesus, expressing trust in Jesus’ healing power—a sign of true belief.

verses.text: Then Jesus said to him, “Unless you see signs and wonders, you will never believe.”
verses.comment: Jesus challenges the crowd's need for miracles but responds to genuine faith. True faith does not always require visible proof.

verses.text: The official said to Him, “Sir, come down before my child dies.”
verses.comment: The official’s plea is personal and humble, a model of intercessory prayer.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, “Go; your son lives.” The man believed the word that Jesus spoke to him and went on his way.
verses.comment: Faith in Christ’s word alone brings healing. This anticipates the faith by which grace is received—before seeing visible results.

verses.text: As he was going down, his servants met him and told him that his son was living.
verses.comment: The healing is confirmed apart from Jesus’ physical presence, emphasizing His divine power and the role of trust.

verses.text: So he asked them the hour when his son began to get better, and they said to him, “Yesterday at the seventh hour the fever left him.”
verses.comment: The exact timing highlights Jesus’ word as the source of healing, confirming His authority.

verses.text: So the father knew that this was the hour when Jesus had said to him, “Your son lives.” And he himself believed, and his whole household.
verses.comment: Faith spreads throughout the household, a pattern seen throughout Scripture. The faith of one can draw a whole family to Christ.

verses.text: This was now the second sign that Jesus did when He had come from Judea to Galilee.
verses.comment: The signs of Jesus are meant to lead to faith in Him as the Messiah and Son of God. Miracles confirm the apostolic witness and point to Christ’s divinity.
